name: 1H-pyrazole-5-methanol, 3-methyl-
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3901
Reason: 1H-pyrazole-5-methanol has a melting point that we can compare to benzene's melting point of 5.5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a methyl group linked in a linear fashion. The methyl group introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point. The pyrazole ring itself also contributes to the melting point due to its rigidity and potential hydrogen bonding. The methyl group can raise the melting point by approximately +10°C due to increased molecular weight and rigidity. The pyrazole ring can also contribute to the melting point due to its rigidity and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +20°C.
